generif.text: Results demonstrate that the alpha5 LG3 module is essential for the Lutheran blood group glycoprotein (Lu) binding to laminin alpha5.
B-CAM/LU is the most critical receptor mediating adhesion to laminin under both static and flow conditions in sickle cell anemia.
interactions of B-CAM and laminin may be involved in progression of epithelial skin tumors
Lu mediates the adhesion of human endothelial cells to alpha5 laminins in collaboration with integrins beta(1) and alpha(v)beta(3).

B-CAM spliceoform seems to be overexpressed by a variety of different malignant tumors and may be involved, along with other adhesion receptor proteins, in malignant transformation and tumor metastasis. (review)
The Laminin 511/521-binding site on the Lutheran blood group glycoprotein is located at the flexible junction of Ig domains 2 and 3.
Observational study of genetic testing. (HuGE Navigator)

study presents a combined modeling & small angle X-ray scattering approach that extends the structural analysis of Lu gp to all five extracellular domains & provides further insight to its interaction with laminins (Ln511 & Ln521)
Observational study of genetic testing. (HuGE Navigator)

Lu/BCAM gps expressed on erythroid or on endothelial cells are involved in SS RBC-endothelium interactions & could play a role in abnormal adhesion of SS RBCs to vascular endothelium contributing to vaso-occlusive crises reported for sickle cell disease.
These results suggest that laminins containing alpha 5 serve as functional substrates regulating progression of hepatocellular carcinoma.
the interaction of the Lu cytoplasmic tail with the cytoskeleton regulates its adhesive receptor function
CD239 was expressed in a constitutive fashion in polycythaemia vera-derived bone marrow cells and thus a pro-thrombotic function does not seem to be mediated by increased CD239 expression alone.
Observational study of genotype prevalence. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of genotype prevalence. (HuGE Navigator)
Lutheran blood group glycoprotein (Lu) is one of the proteins cleaved by MT1-MMP.
Observational study and genome-wide association study of gene-disease association and gene-gene interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
Aggregation of mononuclear and red blood cells through an {alpha}4{beta}1-Lu/basal cell adhesion molecule interaction in sickle cell disease
BCAM glycoproteins are the unique erythroid receptors of laminin alpha5 chain, a major component of the extracellular matrix and are involved in several erythrocyte diseases.

Data indicate that the function-blocking antibody against Lu/B-CAM should be useful for not only investigating cell adhesion to laminin alpha5 but also for developing drugs to inhibit sickle cell vaso-occlusion.

Increases in adhesion frequency provide significant evidence of the role of epinephrine in BCAM/Lu-laminin and ICAM-4-alpha(v)beta(3) bonding, and suggest mechanisms of vaso-occlusion during physical exertion in sickle cell trait.
DARC and BCAM expression was associated with pathogenesis of thyroid carcinoma and correlated with clinical-pathological features.

Glu425 in the Lu glycoprotein is required for expression of Lu7, and Ala425 is associated with the LU:-7 phenotype. This completes the molecular basis associated with all antigens known to be in the Lutheran blood group system.
tumor cell migration on LM-511 requires that Lu/B-CAM competitively modulates cell attachment through integrins.
These studies revealed amino acids 720 to 1014 of CNF1 as the binding site for Lu/BCAM.
Adhesion of sickle reticulocytes to HC-treated endothelial cells was decreased despite the HC-derived increase of Lu/BCAM expression.
High BCAM expression is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.
Through molecular genotyping we also identified polymorphisms in RhCE, Kell, Duffy, Colton, Lutheran and Scianna loci in donors and patients.
The variable levels of expression of mutated JAK2 and BCAM proteins determine different adhesion patterns of erythrocytes from polycythemia vera patients.

Cytometry analysis evidenced a specific expression profile on reticulocytes of SCA infants, with notably an increased expression of the adhesion molecules Lu/BCAM, ICAM-4 and LFA-3, both in percentage of positive cells and in surface density.
The serum levels of IL-8, MIP-1 alpha, MIP-1 beta, MMP-8, Resistin, FLRG, and BCAM were significantly higher in breast cancer patients, but LAP and TSH-beta levels were lower.
four new alleles with coding sequence variants were identified in the LU gene
data show that the BCAM/LAMA5 system plays a functional role in the metastatic spreading of KRAS-mutant colorectal cancer
This is the first report showing that Lu/BCAM, in the presence of its ligand laminin, is oncogenic in human urothelial cancers and may have potential as a novel therapeutic target.
Lu/BCAM-mediated binding to laminin-alpha5 is restricted by interacting, in cis, with glycophorin-C-derived sialic acid residues.
Lu expression by erythrocytes from patients with myeloproliferative neoplasms and splanchnic venous thrombosi is significantly increased compared to erythrocytes from healthy individuals
Lutheran (Lu)/Basal cell adhesion molecule (BCAM) regulates the morphogenesis of DR depending on liver disease models.
Upregulation of BCAM and its sense lncRNA BAN are associated with gastric cancer metastasis and poor prognosis.
Novel variants in Krueppel like factor 1 that cause persistence of fetal hemoglobin in In(Lu) individuals.
Cell trajectory modeling identifies a primitive trophoblast state defined by BCAM enrichment.
Basal cell adhesion molecule promotes metastasis-associated processes in ovarian cancer.

name: basal cell adhesion molecule (Lutheran blood group)
other_names: basal cell adhesion molecule (Lu and Au blood groups)
summary: This gene encodes Lutheran blood group glycoprotein, a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily and a receptor for the extracellular matrix protein, laminin. The protein contains five extracellular immunoglobulin domains, a single transmembrane domain, and a short C-terminal cytoplasmic tail. This protein may play a role in epithelial cell cancer and in vaso-occlusion of red blood cells in sickle cell disease. Polymorphisms in this gene define some of the antigens in the Lutheran system and also the Auberger system. Inactivating variants of this gene result in the recessive Lutheran null phenotype, Lu(a-b-), of the Lutheran blood group. Two transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, May 2012].
